<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<!-- link3 "NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS" -->
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<BR>
Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2"><B>1 </B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2"><B>A. </B>&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>CONSOLIDATION AND BASIS OF PRESENTATION</B>
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">On June&nbsp;19, 2000, we completed our merger with Warner-Lambert Company
(Warner-Lambert). The merger was accounted for as a pooling of interests. As a
result, we restated all prior period consolidated financial statements presented
to reflect the combined results of operations, financial position and cash flows
of both companies as if they had always been merged. Prior to the merger, the
only significant transactions between Pfizer and Warner-Lambert occurred under
the Lipitor marketing agreements. We have eliminated these transactions from the
restated combined financial statements. Certain adjustments and
reclassifications were made to conform the presentation of the restated
financial statements (see note 2, &#147;Merger of Pfizer and Warner-Lambert&#148;).
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include our parent company and all
significant subsidiaries, including those operating outside the U.S. For
subsidiaries operating outside the U.S., balance sheet amounts are as of
November&nbsp;30 of each year and income statement amounts are for the full-year
period ending on the same date. Substantially all unremitted earnings of
international subsidiaries are free of legal and contractual restrictions. All
significant transactions among our businesses have been eliminated. We made
certain reclassifications to the 2000 and 1999 financial statements to conform
to the 2001 presentation.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In preparing the financial statements, we use some estimates and
assumptions that may affect reported amounts and disclosures. Estimates are used
when accounting for sales discounts and incentives, depreciation, amortization,
employee benefits, contingencies and asset valuation allowances. We are also
subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from
estimated results, such as changes in the health care environment, competition,
foreign exchange, litigation, legislation and regulations. &#147;Forward-Looking
Information and Factors That May Affect Future Results&#148; in the accompanying
Financial Review discusses these and other uncertainties.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>B. &nbsp;&nbsp; NEW ACCOUNTING STANDARDS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;1, 2001, we adopted the provisions of the Emerging Issues Task Force
(EITF)&nbsp;Issue No.&nbsp;00-14, Accounting for Certain Sales Incentives, which addresses
the income statement classification of certain sales incentives. As a result, we
reclassified certain sales incentives of $219&nbsp;million in 2000 and $210&nbsp;million
in 1999 from Selling, informational and administrative expenses to Revenues.
These reclassifications have no effect on net income.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;1, 2001, we adopted the provisions of Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards (SFAS)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;138, Accounting for Certain Derivative
Instruments and Certain Hedging Activities &#151; an amendment of SFAS No.&nbsp;133 and
SFAS No.&nbsp;133, Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities. SFAS
No.&nbsp;138 amends the accounting and reporting standards of SFAS No.&nbsp;133 for
certain derivative instruments and certain hedging activities. SFAS No.&nbsp;133
requires us to recognize all derivative instruments as assets or liabilities in
the balance sheet and measure them at fair value. Adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;138 and
SFAS No.&nbsp;133 did not have a material impact on our financial position, results
of operations or cash flows.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>C. &nbsp;&nbsp; CASH EQUIVALENTS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">Cash equivalents include items almost as liquid as cash, such as certificates of
deposit and time deposits with maturity periods of three months or less when
purchased. If items meeting this definition are part of a larger investment
pool, we classify them as Short-term investments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>D. &nbsp;&nbsp; INVENTORIES
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">We value inventories at cost or fair value, if lower. Cost is determined as
follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">finished goods and work-in-process at average actual cost</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">raw materials and supplies at average or latest actual cost</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>E. &nbsp;&nbsp; LONG-LIVED ASSETS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">Long-lived assets include:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">property, plant and equipment &#151; These assets are recorded at
original cost and increased by the cost of any significant
improvements after purchase. We depreciate the cost evenly over the
assets&#146; estimated useful lives. For tax purposes, accelerated
depreciation methods are used as allowed by tax laws.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">goodwill &#151; Goodwill represents the difference between the purchase
price of acquired businesses and the fair value of their net assets
when accounted for by the purchase method. We amortize goodwill
evenly over periods not exceeding 40&nbsp;years. The average amortization
period is 38&nbsp;years.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">other intangible assets &#151; Other intangible assets are included in
Other assets, deferred taxes and deferred charges. We amortize these
assets evenly over their estimated useful lives.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We review long-lived assets to assess recoverability from future
operations using undiscounted cash flows. When necessary, we record charges for
impairments of long-lived assets for the amount by which the present value of
future cash flows is less than the carrying value of these assets.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">44</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>F. &nbsp;&nbsp; FOREIGN CURRENCY TRANSLATION
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">For most international operations, local currencies are considered their
functional currencies. We translate assets and liabilities to their U.S. dollar
equivalents at rates in effect at the balance sheet date and record translation
adjustments in Shareholders&#146; Equity. We translate statement of income accounts
at average rates for the period. Transaction adjustments are recorded in Other
income &#151; net.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For operations in highly inflationary economies, we translate the balance
sheet items as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">monetary items (that is, assets and liabilities that will be settled
for cash) at rates in effect at the balance sheet date, with
translation adjustments recorded in Other income &#151; net</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">non-monetary items at historical rates (that is, those rates in
effect when the items were first recorded)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>G. &nbsp;&nbsp; REVENUE RECOGNITION
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">We record revenue from product sales when the goods are shipped and title passes
to the customer. Other current liabilities included accruals for customer
rebates of $695&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and $932&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,
2000.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have agreements to promote pharmaceutical products discovered by other
companies. Revenue is earned when our co-promotion partners ship the related
products and title passes to the customer. Our revenue is primarily based upon a
percentage of our co-promotion partners&#146; net sales. Generally, expenses for
selling and marketing these products are included in Selling, informational and
administrative expenses.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>H. &nbsp;&nbsp; STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;123, Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation, we
elected to account for our stock-based compensation under Accounting Principles
Board Opinion (APB)&nbsp;No.&nbsp;25, Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The exercise price of stock options granted equals the market price on the
date of grant. There is no recorded expense related to grants of stock options.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>I. &nbsp;&nbsp; ADVERTISING EXPENSE
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">We record advertising expense as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">production costs as incurred</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">costs of radio time, television time and space in publications are
deferred until the advertising occurs</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Advertising expense totaled approximately $2,863&nbsp;million in 2001, $3,184
million in 2000 and $3,082&nbsp;million in 1999.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>J. &nbsp;&nbsp; SHIPPING AND HANDLING COSTS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">Shipping and handling costs are included in Selling, informational and
administrative expenses. Shipping and handling costs totaled approximately $199
million in 2001, $190&nbsp;million in 2000 and $181&nbsp;million in 1999.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; MERGER OF PFIZER AND WARNER-LAMBERT
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">On June&nbsp;19, 2000, we completed our merger with Warner-Lambert. We issued
approximately 2,440&nbsp;million shares of our common stock for all the outstanding
common stock of Warner-Lambert.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The merger qualified as a tax-free reorganization and was accounted for as
a pooling of interests under APB No.&nbsp;16, Business Combinations.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The results of operations for the separate companies and the combined
amounts presented in the consolidated financial statements for the prior periods
presented follow:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">

        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>

        <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#eeeeee">
        <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Revenues:</FONT></DIV></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD><TR><TD><TR><TD><TR><TD>
<TR valign="bottom">
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

        <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 1999, we adjusted for the impact of a
change in the calculation of Warner-Lambert&#146;s pension asset to conform to
our method of calculating fair value. For the three months ended April&nbsp;2,

had always been combined.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May 1999, Warner-Lambert acquired Agouron Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
(Agouron), a pharmaceutical company committed to the discovery and development
of innovative therapeutic products for the treatment of cancer, AIDS and other
serious diseases. Warner-Lambert exchanged 28.8&nbsp;million shares of its common
stock for all of the common stock of Agouron.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The transaction was accounted for as a pooling of interests and qualified
as a tax-free reorganization. Accordingly, all prior period consolidated
financial statements presented have been restated to include combined results of
operations, financial position and cash flows of Agouron as though it had always
been a part of Warner-Lambert. Prior to the merger, Agouron&#146;s fiscal year ended
on June&nbsp;30. As a result, Agouron&#146;s financial statements were restated to conform
with Warner-Lambert&#146;s December&nbsp;31&nbsp;year end. Certain reclassifications were made
to the Agouron financial statements to conform to Warner-Lambert&#146;s presentation.
No adjustments were necessary to conform Agouron&#146;s accounting policies. The
impact of combining Agouron&#146;s financial statements with ours was not material to
the consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">45</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
      <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">*</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Included in Other current liabilities.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Through December&nbsp;31, 2001, the charges for employee termination costs
represent the approved reduction of our work force by 6,691 people, mainly
comprising administrative functions for corporate, manufacturing, distribution,
sales and research. We notified these people and as of December&nbsp;31, 2001, 6,338
employees were terminated. We will complete terminations of the remaining
personnel within one year of their notification. Employee termination costs
include accrued severance benefits and costs associated with change-in-control
provisions of certain Warner-Lambert employment contracts. Under the terms of
these Warner-Lambert employment contracts, certain terminated employees may
elect to defer receipt of severance benefits. Severance benefits deferred for
future payments were $215&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and $177&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2000. The deferred severance benefits are considered utilized
charges and are included in Other noncurrent liabilities.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property, plant and equipment charges include the impairment and disposal
costs from the consolidation of facilities and related fixed assets, a contract
termination payment and termination of certain software installation projects.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other restructuring charges primarily consist of charges for contract
termination payments &#151; $27&nbsp;million in 2001 and $16&nbsp;million in 2000; facility
closure costs &#151; $2&nbsp;million in 2001 and $4&nbsp;million in 2000 and assets we wrote
off, including inventory and intangible assets &#151; $1&nbsp;million in 2001 and $5
million in 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>4 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">In 2001, we resolved several post-closing matters associated with certain of our
previously discontinued businesses, resulting in income of $60&nbsp;million ($36
million after-tax).
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2000, we determined working capital settlement amounts and settled a
lawsuit for certain of our previously discontinued businesses, resulting in
income of $14&nbsp;million ($8&nbsp;million after-tax).
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 1999, we agreed to pay a fine of $20&nbsp;million to settle antitrust
charges involving our former Food Science Group.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Discontinued operations &#151; net of tax were as follows:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>B. &nbsp;&nbsp; SHORT-TERM BORROWINGS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">The weighted average effective interest rate on short-term borrowings
outstanding at December&nbsp;31 was 2.4% in 2001 and 4.7% in 2000. At December&nbsp;31,
2001, we had approximately $2.8&nbsp;billion lines of credit which expire within one
year. Of these lines of credit, $2.5&nbsp;billion are unused of which our lenders
have committed to loan us $704&nbsp;million at our request.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>C. &nbsp;&nbsp; LONG-TERM DEBT

<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
      <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">*</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes unrealized gains and losses for debt with fair value hedges in 2001
(see note 6-D, &#147;Derivative Financial Instruments and Hedging Activities&#148;).</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The floating-rate unsecured notes bear interest at a defined variable rate
based on the commercial paper borrowing rate. The weighted average interest rate
was 2.1% at December&nbsp;31, 2001. These notes minimize credit risk on certain
available-for-sale debt securities that may be used to satisfy the notes at
maturity.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2001, we issued the following unsecured notes under a $2.5&nbsp;billion
shelf registration filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in October
2000:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">In October, we issued $600&nbsp;million senior unsecured notes which pay
interest semi-annually, beginning on May&nbsp;1, 2002 at a rate of
3.625%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">In May, we issued 60&nbsp;billion yen ($489&nbsp;million at date of issuance)
unsecured notes which pay interest semi-annually, beginning on
September&nbsp;18, 2001, at a rate of .80%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

interest semi-annually, beginning on August&nbsp;1, 2001, at a rate of
5.625%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The proceeds from the note issuances were used for general corporate
purposes.
</FONT>

        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>

</CENTER>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">47</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>D. &nbsp;&nbsp; DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS AND HEDGING ACTIVITIES
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following disclosures relate to derivative and hedging instruments as of
December&nbsp;31, 2001:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>PURPOSE
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Foreign Exchange Risk
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A significant portion of revenues, earnings and net investments in foreign
affiliates are exposed to changes in foreign exchange rates. We seek to manage
our foreign exchange risk in part through operational means, including managing
expected local currency revenues in relation to local currency costs and local
currency assets in relation to local currency liabilities. Foreign exchange risk
is also managed through the use of derivative financial instruments and foreign
currency denominated debt. These financial instruments serve to protect net
income against the impact of the translation into U.S. dollars of certain
foreign exchange denominated transactions. At December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000, the
financial instruments are as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$3,627&nbsp;million in 2001 and $3,827&nbsp;million in 2000 notional amount of
foreign currency forward-exchange contracts are used to offset the
potential earnings effects from short-term foreign currency assets
and liabilities in mostly intercompany cross-border transactions
that arise from operations. We have entered into such contracts
primarily to sell euro, U.K. pound and Japanese yen in exchange for
U.S. dollars.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$1,155&nbsp;million of short-term and $457&nbsp;million of long-term Japanese
yen debt in 2001 and $1,262&nbsp;million of short-term debt in 2000 is
designated as a net investment hedge of our yen net investments in
operations in order to limit the risk of adverse changes in the
value of such investments related to foreign exchange.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$428&nbsp;million in 2001 and $426&nbsp;million in 2000 notional amount of
foreign currency swaps are designated as cash flow hedges of a U.K.
pound intercompany loan maturing in 2003.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$160&nbsp;million in 2001 and $36&nbsp;million in 2000 notional amount of
foreign currency swaps are designated as fair value hedges of euro
debt investments maturing through mid-2003.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$146&nbsp;million in 2001 and $69&nbsp;million in 2000 notional amount of
foreign currency swaps are designated as fair value hedges of U.K.
pound debt investments maturing through mid-2002.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$90&nbsp;million in 2001 and $52&nbsp;million in 2000 notional amount of
foreign currency swaps are designated as fair value hedges of a
foreign subsidiary&#146;s euro loans. The loans and foreign currency
swaps matured in December 2001.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Rate Risk
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our interest-bearing investments, loans and borrowings are subject to
interest rate risk. We invest and borrow primarily on a short-term or
variable-rate basis. Significant interest rate risk is also managed through the
use of derivative financial instruments as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$924&nbsp;million in 2001 and $1,056&nbsp;million in 2000 notional amount of
yen interest rate swaps maturing in 2003 are designated as cash flow
hedges of the yen &#147;LIBOR&#148; interest rate related to forecasted
issuances of short-term debt. These swaps serve to reduce the
variability of the yen interest rate by effectively fixing the rates
on short-term debt at 1.2%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$600&nbsp;million notional amount of interest rate swaps maturing in late
2004, $750&nbsp;million notional amount of U.S. dollar interest rate
swaps maturing in 2006, and $250&nbsp;million interest rate swaps
maturing in early 2008 are designated as fair value hedges of the
changes in the fair value of fixed-rate debt. These swaps serve to
reduce our exposure to long-term U.S. dollar interest rates by
effectively converting the fixed rates associated with the majority
of our long-term debt obligations to floating rates.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">$95&nbsp;million notional amount of U.S. dollar interest rate swaps
maturing in late 2004 are designated as cash flow hedges of &#147;LIBOR&#148;
interest rates related to forecasted purchases of short-term fixed
rate debt investments to be classified as available-for-sale
securities. These swaps serve to reduce the variability of &#147;LIBOR&#148;
interest rates by effectively fixing the rates on short-term debt
securities at 3.5%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">In 2001, all derivative contracts are reported at fair value, with changes in
fair value reported in earnings or deferred, depending on the nature and
effectiveness of the offset or hedging relationship, as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">Foreign Exchange Risk</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of foreign currency
forward-exchange contracts during the terms of the contracts, along
with the earnings impact of the items they generally offset.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of foreign currency swaps
designated as cash flow or fair value hedges upon the recognition of
the foreign exchange gain or loss on the translation to U.S. dollars
of the hedged item.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">Interest Rate Risk</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of interest rate swaps designated
as cash flow hedges upon the recognition of the interest related to
the hedged short-term debt and available-for-sale debt securities.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">We recognize the earnings impact of interest rate swaps designated
as fair value hedges upon the recognition of the change in fair
value for interest rate risk related to the hedged long-term debt.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Any ineffectiveness in a hedging relationship is recognized immediately
into earnings. There was no significant ineffectiveness in 2001 and 2000.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2000, most derivative contracts were reported at contractual receipt or
payable value.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">48</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Purchased currency options are recorded at cost and amortized evenly to
operations through the expected inventory delivery date. Further, gains at the
delivery date are included in the cost of the related inventory purchased.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The financial statements include the following items related to the
derivatives and other financial instruments serving as hedges or offsets:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>E. &nbsp;&nbsp; FAIR VALUE
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">The following methods and assumptions were used to estimate the fair value of
derivative and other financial instruments at the balance sheet date:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">short-term financial instruments (cash equivalents, accounts
receivable and payable, forward-exchange contracts, short-term
investments and borrowings) &#151; cost or contract value approximates
fair value because of the short maturity period or in 2001 foreign
forward-exchange contracts are reported at fair value</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">loans &#151; cost approximates fair value because of the short interest-
reset period</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">long-term investments, long-term debt and forward-exchange contracts
&#151;fair value is based on valuation models that use market quotes</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
        <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="91%"><FONT size="2">interest rate and foreign currency swap agreements &#151; fair value is
based on estimated cost to terminate the agreements (taking into
account current interest and foreign exchange rates and the
counterparties&#146; creditworthiness)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The differences between the fair values and carrying values of our
derivative and other financial instruments were not material at December&nbsp;31,
2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>F. &nbsp;&nbsp; CREDIT RISK
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">We periodically review the creditworthiness of counterparties to foreign
exchange and interest rate agreements and do not expect to incur a loss from
failure of any counterparties to perform under the agreements. In general, there
is no requirement for collateral from customers. There are no significant
concentrations of credit risk related to our financial instruments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>7 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; COMPREHENSIVE INCOME
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">Changes in accumulated other comprehensive expense follow:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">
<TR valign="bottom">
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="26%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>

        <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

        <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

        <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR valign="top">
      <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">*</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Income tax benefit for other comprehensive expense was $163&nbsp;million in 1999,
$232&nbsp;million in 2000 and $146&nbsp;million in 2001.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

includes:
</FONT>

        <TD nowrap align="center"><FONT size="1"><B>(millions of dollars)</B></FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><FONT size="1"><B>2001</B></FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">49</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; INVENTORIES
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">In March 2000, we announced that we were discontinuing the sale of Rezulin. In
2000, we recorded charges of $136&nbsp;million ($120&nbsp;million after-tax, or $.02
after-tax per diluted share) in Other income &#151; net for the one-time costs,
which include inventory write-offs, associated with the withdrawal of Rezulin.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 1999, the European Union&#146;s Committee for Proprietary Medicinal
Products suspended the European Union licenses of the oral and intravenous
formulations of Trovan. Based on our evaluation of these events and related
matters, in the third quarter of 1999 we recorded a charge of $310&nbsp;million ($205
million after-tax, or $.03 after-tax per diluted share) in Cost of sales to
write off Trovan inventories in excess of the amount required to support
expected sales.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT

<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Amounts are reflected in the preceding tables based on the location of the
taxing authorities. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, we have not made a U.S. tax
provision on approximately $18&nbsp;billion of unremitted earnings of our
international subsidiaries. These earnings are expected, for the most part, to
be reinvested overseas. It is not practical to compute the estimated deferred
tax liability on these earnings.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We operate manufacturing subsidiaries in Puerto Rico that benefit from
Puerto Rican incentive grants that expire at the end of 2015. Under the grants,
we are partially exempt from income, property and municipal taxes. Under Section
936 of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code, Pfizer is a &#147;grandfathered&#148; entity and is
entitled to the benefits under such statute until 2006.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">50</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>


<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred taxes arise because of different treatment between financial
statement accounting and tax accounting, known as &#147;temporary differences.&#148; We
record the tax effect of these temporary differences as &#147;deferred tax assets&#148;
(generally items that can be used as a tax deduction or credit in future
periods) and &#147;deferred tax liabilities&#148; (generally items that we received a tax
deduction for, which have not yet been recorded in the statement of income).
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The tax effects of the major items recorded as deferred tax assets and
liabilities are:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">

        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A valuation allowance is recorded because some items recorded as deferred
tax assets may not be deductible or creditable. The foreign tax credit
carryforwards were generated from dividends paid or deemed to be paid by
subsidiaries to the parent company between 1997 and 2001. We can carry these
credits forward for five years from the year of actual payment and apply them to
certain U.S. tax liabilities.
</FONT>

taxing location, are in the following captions in the balance sheet:

</CENTER>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Internal Revenue Service (IRS)&nbsp;has completed and closed its audits of
our tax returns through 1995. The IRS is currently conducting audits of our tax
returns for the years 1996 through 1998.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 1994, Belgian tax authorities notified Pfizer Research and
Development Company N.V./S.A. (PRDCO), an indirect, wholly owned subsidiary of
our company, of a proposed adjustment to the taxable income of PRDCO for fiscal
year 1992. The proposed adjustment arises from an assertion by the Belgian tax
authorities of jurisdiction with respect to income resulting primarily from
certain transfers of property by our non-Belgian subsidiaries to the Irish
branch of PRDCO. In January 1995, PRDCO received an assessment from the tax
authorities for additional taxes and interest of approximately $432&nbsp;million and
$97&nbsp;million, respectively, relating to these matters. In January 1996, PRDCO
received an assessment from the tax authorities, for fiscal year 1993, for
additional taxes and interest of approximately $86&nbsp;million and $18&nbsp;million,
respectively. The additional assessment arises from the same assertion by the
Belgian tax authorities of jurisdiction with respect to all income of the Irish
branch of PRDCO. Based upon the relevant facts regarding the Irish branch of
PRDCO and the provisions of the Belgian tax laws and the written opinions of
outside counsel, we believe that the assessments are without merit.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe that our accrued tax liabilities are adequate for all years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>12 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; BENEFIT PLANS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">We provide defined benefit pension plans and defined contribution plans for the
majority of employees worldwide. We also provide benefits through supplemental
retirement plans to employees. These unfunded supplemental plans provide out of
our general assets an amount substantially equal to the difference between the
amounts that would have been payable under the defined benefit pension plans, in
the absence of legislation limiting pension benefits and earnings that may be
considered in calculating pension benefits, and the amounts actually payable
under the defined benefit pension plans. In addition, we provide medical and
life insurance benefits to retirees and their eligible dependents through our
postretirement plans.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We fund our pension plans in amounts sufficient to meet the requirements
set forth in applicable employee benefits laws and local tax laws. Liabilities
for amounts in excess of these funding levels are accrued and reported in our
consolidated balance sheet.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our plan assets comprise a diversified mix of assets including corporate
equities, government securities and corporate debt securities. Certain
international subsidiaries have plans where reserves are provided or annuities
are purchased under group contracts.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2001, the major U.S. pension plans held approximately 7.7
million shares of our common stock with a fair value of approximately $307
million. The plans received approximately $3&nbsp;million in dividends on these
shares in 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">51</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table provides the weighted average actuarial assumptions
used to develop net periodic benefit cost and the actuarial present value of
projected benefit obligations.
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">

</CENTER>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The periodic benefit cost and the actuarial present value of projected
benefit obligations are based on actuarial assumptions that are reviewed on an
annual basis. We revise these assumptions based on an annual evaluation of
long-term trends, as well as market conditions, that may have an impact on the
cost of providing retirement benefits and in accordance with the requirements of
SFAS No.&nbsp;87, Employers&#146; Accounting for Pensions.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The annual cost related to the U.S. and international plans follow:

<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in the underfunded status of the pension plans in 2001 results
primarily from a decrease in the discount rate used in calculating plan
liabilities coupled with the effect on plan assets of adverse capital markets
performance. In response to these developments, we increased our contributions
to certain plans.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">52</FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plans with accumulated benefit obligations and projected benefit

supplemental retirement plans, as well as certain international plans whose
liabilities are typically accrued for and reported in our consolidated balance
sheet.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An average increase of 9% in the cost of health care benefits was assumed
for 2002 and is projected to decrease over the next six years to 5% and to then
remain at that level.
</FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have savings and investment plans in several countries including the
U.S. and Puerto Rico. Employees may contribute a portion of their salaries to
the plans and we match a portion of the employee contributions. Our
contributions were $107&nbsp;million in 2001, $86&nbsp;million in 2000 and $80&nbsp;million in
1999.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>13 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; LEASE COMMITMENTS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">We lease properties and equipment for use in our operations. In addition to
rent, the leases may require us to pay directly for taxes, insurance,
maintenance and other operating expenses, or to pay higher rent when operating
expenses increase. Rental expense, net of sublease income, was $300&nbsp;million in
2001, $318&nbsp;million in 2000 and $295&nbsp;million in 1999. This table shows future
minimum rental commitments under noncancellable operating leases at December&nbsp;31,
2001:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>14 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; COMMON STOCK
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">In June 2001, we announced a new $5&nbsp;billion share-purchase program, with a limit
of 120&nbsp;million shares to be made over a consecutive 18&nbsp;month period in the open
market or in privately negotiated transactions. In May 2001, we completed the $5
billion share-purchase program begun in September 1998. Under this program, we
purchased, in total, approximately 127&nbsp;million shares at a total cost of $5
billion.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2001, we purchased approximately 68.5&nbsp;million shares of our common stock
in the open market at an average price of $40.83 per share under the June 2001
share-purchase program and approximately 20.3&nbsp;million shares of our common stock
at an average price of $42.72 per share under the September 1998 share-purchase
program. In 2000, we purchased approximately 23.1&nbsp;million shares of our common
stock in the open market at an average price of $43.46 per share. In 1999, we
purchased approximately 65.6&nbsp;million shares of our common stock in the open
market at an average price of $38 per share.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We effected a three-for-one stock split of our common stock in the form of
a 200% stock dividend in 1999. All share and per share information in this
report reflects the stock split. Per share data may reflect rounding adjustments
as a result of the stock split.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">53</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>15 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; PREFERRED STOCK PURCHASE RIGHTS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">Preferred Stock Purchase Rights have a scheduled term through October 2007,
although the term may be extended or the Rights may be redeemed prior to
expiration. One right was issued for each share of common stock issued by our
company. These rights are not exercisable unless certain change-in-control
events transpire, such as a person acquiring or obtaining the right to acquire
beneficial ownership of 15% or more of our outstanding common stock or an
announcement of a tender offer for at least 30% of our stock. The rights are
evidenced by corresponding common stock certificates and automatically trade
with the common stock unless an event transpires that makes them exercisable. If
the rights become exercisable, separate certificates evidencing the rights will
be distributed and each right will entitle the holder to purchase a new series
of preferred stock at a defined price from our company. The preferred stock, in
addition to preferred dividend and liquidation rights, will entitle the holder
to vote with the company&#146;s common stock.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The rights are redeemable by us at a fixed price until 10&nbsp;days, or longer
as determined by the Board, after certain defined events, or at any time prior
to the expiration of the rights.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have reserved 3.0&nbsp;million preferred shares to be issued pursuant to
these rights. No such shares have yet been issued. At the present time, the
rights have no dilutive effect on the earnings per common share calculation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>16 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; EMPLOYEE BENEFIT TRUSTS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">In 1993, we sold 120&nbsp;million shares of treasury stock to the Pfizer Inc. Grantor
Trust in exchange for a $600&nbsp;million note. The Trust was established primarily
to fund our employee benefit plans. In February 1999, the Trust transferred 10
million shares to us to satisfy the balance due on its note and contributed its
remaining 90&nbsp;million shares to the newly established Pfizer Inc. Employee
Benefit Trust (EBT). The Grantor Trust was then dissolved. Shares of the EBT are
used to fund employee benefit plans. The balance sheet reflects the fair value
of the shares owned by the EBT as a reduction of Shareholders&#146; Equity.
</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock options and stock issuable under employee compensation plans
representing equivalents of 136&nbsp;million shares of common stock during 2001 and
115&nbsp;million shares of common stock during 1999 had exercise prices greater than
the average market price of Pfizer common stock. These common stock equivalents
were outstanding during 2001 and 1999, but were not included in the computation
of diluted earnings per share for those years because their inclusion would have
had an antidilutive effect. There were no antidilutive common share equivalents
during 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">54</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>18 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; STOCK OPTION AND PERFORMANCE UNIT AWARDS
</B></FONT>

<P><FONT size="2">We have stock and incentive plans related to employees which allow for stock
options, performance unit awards and stock awards.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We may grant stock options to employees, including officers, under the
plans. Options are exercisable after five years or less, subject to continuous
employment and certain other conditions, and expire 10&nbsp;years after the grant
date. Once exercisable, the employee can purchase shares of our common stock at
the market price on the date we granted the option. The 1996 Stock Plan, a
former Warner-Lambert plan, provided that, in the event of a change in control
of Warner-Lambert, stock options already granted became exercisable immediately.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Shares available for award (in thousands) at:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="45%">
<TR valign="bottom">
        <TD width="70%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="12%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="12%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
        <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">- December&nbsp;31, 1999</FONT></TD>
        <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD nowrap align="right" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
        <TD align="right" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
198,423</FONT></TD>
        <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<P><FONT size="2">Options granted in 1999 include options for 450 shares granted to every eligible
pre-merger Pfizer employee worldwide in celebration of our 150th Anniversary.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">The tax benefits related to certain stock option transactions were $395&nbsp;million
in 2001, $1,306&nbsp;million in 2000 and $470&nbsp;million in 1999.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The weighted-average fair value per stock option granted was $15.12 for
2001, $11.12 for 2000 and $11.79 for 1999. We estimated the fair values using
the Black-Scholes option pricing model, modified for dividends and using the
following assumptions:

<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2001, our shareholders approved a new Performance-Contingent Share Award
Plan (the Plan) allowing a maximum of 12.5&nbsp;million shares to be awarded. The
Plan replaces the Performance-Contingent Share Award Program (the Program) that
was established and became effective in 1993 to provide executives and other key
employees the right to earn common stock awards. Similar to the previous
Program, determination of award payouts under the Plan is made after the
performance period ends, based upon specific performance criteria. Under the
previous Program, up to 120&nbsp;million shares could be awarded. The actual number
of shares awarded and pending under the previous Program since its approval is
approximately 20&nbsp;million shares. At December&nbsp;31, 2001, participants had the
right to earn up to 11.0&nbsp;million additional shares under the old Program. All
awards beginning in 2002 and later will be made under the new Plan and all
previous awards that may have extended performance periods will be made under
the previous Program. Under the previous Program, we awarded approximately 1.7
million shares in 2001, approximately 2.3&nbsp;million shares in 2000, and
approximately 2.3&nbsp;million shares in 1999. We did not award any shares under the
new Plan as of December&nbsp;31, 2001. Compensation expense related to the previous
Program was $94&nbsp;million in 2001, $170&nbsp;million in 2000 and $64&nbsp;million in 1999.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">55</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We entered into two forward-purchase contracts in 1999 which were
subsequently extended. These contracts offset the potential impact on net income
of our liability under the Program. At settlement date we will, at the option of
the counterparty to each of the contracts, either receive our own stock or
settle the contracts for cash. Other contract terms are as follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">
<TR valign="bottom">
        <TD width="33%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="17%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="18%">&nbsp;</TD>
        <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>

contracts:
</FONT>
